children.text: Your instructor should have let you know if you are uploading annotations to AVAnnotate yourself or if they will be uploading them on your behalf.
If you are uploading your annotations to your own AVAnnotate project, please refer to your instructors directions for naming conventions and format of your project.
If your annotations will be uploaded by your instructor, please be sure you submit your annotations to your instructor.
Once annotations have been added to AVAnnotate, explore the full class project (with annotations from both clips) and respond in writing to the following:
Compare your annotation choices to others who annotated the same clip. Did people transcribe? If so, did they transcribe the same thing? Why/why not?
Look at annotations from the other clip. How did students organize their annotations differently? Would that change how someone engages with the project?
Now, reflect on the following questions:
What was the most engaging part of listening to this recording for you? The most challenging? What did you do to manage?
How did the process of creating annotations change the way you listened to or understood the recording? How will they impact how someone else listens to the recording?
What struck you most about how the recordings, separately and when put together? What did you learn about the power of language, both in sharing experiences and as a way to weaponize power?Â
What is one thing you can take from this recording into your life today?
